intro: Gonolobus calcaratus, commonly known as the sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pink, and its hairy, often glandular leaves. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. It is a member of the Verbenaceae family and is often found in coastal dunes or dry slopes. Gonolobus calcaratus is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
